abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Kerala State Transport
            Project for India were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was moderately satisfactory and borrower
            performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned includes: project preparation. The period between
            the completion of the preparation and commencement of
            implementation should be minimized (preferably should be
            within one year) to avoid major variations of the existing
            physical conditions of pavement. Raising awareness for
            financing such single state projects, substantive capacity
            building and training on safeguards, environmental,
            financial and procurement aspects should be planned for the
            project implementation agency (PWD). Safeguards management
            aspects were environmental aspect, social aspects. The
            introduction of the direct purchase method allowed the
            Project affected peoples PAPs to participate in the process
            of fixing land value and a fair chance to demand for due
            price for their asset loss. Effective and efficient project
            management implementing agency's project management
            unit should be put in place including key personnel before
            mobilization of contractor with due authority of decision
            making to manage the project. Contract management aspects
            sites for disposal of waste/surplus material satisfying
            environmental criteria should be indicated at the early
            stage to allow proper pricing by the bidders.

repnme.cdata!: India - Kerala State Transport Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Kerala State
            Transport Project (KSTP) for India are: (a) to improve
            traffic flow and road safety on the state's primary
            road network, and (b) strengthen institutional and financial
            capacities of the key transport sector agencies. The
            changes, involving modifications in project outcome
            indicator targets, will constitute a first order project
            restructuring. The restructuring is aimed towards partially
            mitigating the loss of time and cost savings benefits
            arising from exclusion of the second phase corridor
            improvement works. Moreover, through the restructuring, the
            project development impact can be extended by bringing in
            additional 200 km of primary road network under improved
            periodic maintenance and safety management framework.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Kerala State Transport Project :
            environmental impact assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Kerala State Transport Project
            includes the improvement and maintenance of the existing
            State Highways and major district roads, and a pilot
            waterways component. For the road component, a number of
            additional structures will be provided in new alignment
            areas for better drainage. Riverbanks as well as riverbeds
            are suffering from erosion. Retaining walls will be
            constructed in areas where the expected erosion rates are
            high. Quarrying will be carried out at approved and licensed
            sites. Potential sources of noise pollution will be
            controlled by strict procedures for issuing and controlling
            driving licenses, noise pollution legislation, and noise
            barriers. Tree removals must be approved by the authorities
            and trees must be replaced by planting at least twice the
            number removed. In the waterways component, a portion of the
            side bunds are prone to erosion. Quarrying of construction
            material will be restricted to licensed contractors. The
            side bunds will be reconstructed and will constitute the
            single largest share of the total investment for the
            implementation of the project. The water quality is already
            known to be poor and will require a comprehensive approach,
            rather than the scope of this project, to clean up the pollution.

display_title.display_title:
India - Kerala State Transport
            Project : environmental impact assessment (Vol. 10) :
            Implementation plan
